p: In the human gut ecosystem, temperate bacteriophages dominate over lytic bacteriophages [ 13â€“ 15]. It is believed that the majority of bacterial cells have at least one phage inserted into their genome, the so-called prophage. Some prophages may be incorporated in bacterial genomes for millions of generations, losing their ability to excise from host genomes because of genetic erosion (degradation and deletion processes) [ 16]. These prophages, which are called cryptic or defective, have been shown to be important for the fitness of the bacterial host [ 17] and thus represent an essential part of a bacterial genome.
